hero.headline: Calm, client-led, ICF-aligned coaching for real transitions.
hero.subheadline: Whether you are relocating, returning to work, or navigating cultural differences, we create space to orient, decide, and move with consent.
hero.imageAlt: Notebook, tea, and sunlight suggesting a calm coaching space.

forWhom.title: Who it’s for
forWhom.description: A glimpse of pathways shaped around the contexts we coach most often.

cards.title: Transition coaching
cards.target: For people settling into a new country or chapter.
cards.scenario: You are building a life in the UK while keeping commitments elsewhere.
questions: What agreements help you feel rooted when obligations pull in different directions?
How do you honour grief, curiosity, and agency as you land?

cards.title: Early-career coaching
cards.target: For people figuring out their early career moves.
cards.scenario: You want honest space to test directions before committing.
questions: Which options feel exciting, safe, or both?
How can you experiment without pretending you “have it all together”?

cards.title: Working parent coaching
cards.target: For carers, parents, and professionals re-entering paid roles.
cards.scenario: You are rebuilding confidence after time away or a role change.
questions: What rhythms sustain both your responsibilities and your growth?
Which stories about readiness or worthiness need reframing?

cards.title: Leadership coaching
cards.scenario: You are translating ideas across UK norms, accents, and expectations.
questions: Where do you want more ease in speaking up or setting boundaries?
What support systems anchor you when feedback styles differ?

recognise.title: You might recognise this
items: You moved to the UK and are unsure which workplace norms to follow.
You want to return to work without losing the care agreements that matter at home.
You speak multiple languages yet hesitate when conversations turn fast or nuanced.
You are balancing visas, family expectations, and your own leadership plans.
You sense burnout signals and want to experiment before things fracture.

steps.title: Co-create the focus
steps.description: Each session starts with what feels most present—no scripts, no rush to fix.

steps.title: Hold autonomy
steps.description: You choose directions and pace while we reflect patterns, options, and consent.

steps.title: Test small moves
steps.description: We design light experiments you can try between sessions and review what emerges.

steps.title: Close with clarity
steps.description: We gather insights, name supports, and respect boundaries for next steps.

items.question: How is coaching different from therapy?
items.answer: Coaching focuses on your present goals and future actions. We collaborate as equals and do not diagnose or treat mental health conditions. When therapy or other support is better suited, we name that together.

items.question: Is our conversation confidential?
items.answer: Yes. Sessions stay between us unless the law requires disclosure or there is risk of harm. We agree on how notes are stored and when information may be shared before we begin.

items.question: What outcomes can I expect?
items.answer: We do not promise specific results. Most clients leave sessions with clearer language, grounded decisions, and experiments they chose. You stay in charge of implementing what feels right.

items.question: Can we coach in more than one language?
items.answer: Absolutely. We switch between English and Mandarin when it helps you express nuance. Cultural references and metaphors are welcome in the room.

items.question: How do I know if coaching is the right support?
items.answer: The intro chat is a space to explore that question. We will clarify what you need, share how coaching fits, and suggest next steps—including other resources—if coaching is not appropriate.

items.question: What happens after the intro call?
items.answer: If we decide to continue, we agree on session length, frequency, fees, and review points. Everything moves at a pace that respects your commitments.
